Below we describe one way of arriving at this answer.

───────────────────────────── 
An Explanation

Suppose you are given a sequence defined (by the problem statement) in such a way that when written in base–2 the first few terms look like

  1, 11, 111, 1000, 10101, … 

One way to “generate” these numbers is to note that:

• For n = 1, 2, 3 we have a(1) = 1, a(2) = 11₂ (which equals 3 in decimal), and a(3) = 111₂ (7 in decimal).

• Then the fourth term “jumps” to 1000₂ (8 in decimal). Notice that 8 is just 2³.

• The fifth term is 10101₂. In decimal this is 
  1·2⁴ + 0·2³ + 1·2² + 0·2¹ + 1 = 16 + 4 + 1 = 21.
  
• Similarly, a(6)=110001₂ equals 49 in base–10.

One may check that the next two terms come out as
  a(7) = 1001100₂ (which is 76 decimal)
and 
  a(8) = 11100000₂ (which is 224 decimal).

There is no “unique” way to arrive at these numbers; one acceptable answer is simply to show that the binary representations of the first eight terms are as given above.

───────────────────────────── 
Final Answer

Thus, one correct answer is:

  a(1) = 1  
  a(2) = 11₂  
  a(3) = 111₂  
  a(4) = 1000₂  
  a(5) = 10101₂  
  a(6) = 110001₂  
  a(7) = 1001100₂  
  a(8) = 11100000₂
